5667
THE JOURNAL OF BIOLOGICAL CHEMISTRY (- 1905 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecule Biology, Inc.
Vel. 270, No. 19, Issue of May 12, pp. 11502- 11513, 1995 Printed in UR.A
Analysis of the Hormone-dependent Regulation of a JunD-Estrogen Receptor Chimera*
(Received for publication, November 14, 1994, and in revised form, February 1, 1995)
Mary Kay Francist, Donald G. Phinneys, and Kevin Rydert
From the Fox Chase Cancer Center, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19111
The modular ligand-binding domains of steroid recep- tors have been widely used to generate protein chimeras that are ligand dependent for activity. In a similar man- ner, we generated a series of conditionally active JunD) and c-Fos proteins by fusing their carboxyl (COOH)- terminal ends with a COOH-terminal fragment of the human estrogen receptor (KR) that contains the ligand- binding domain. JunD-ER (DER) and Fos-ER (FER) chi- meras with an intact leucine zipper and basic region exhibit hormone-dependent activation of activator pro- tein-1-directed transcription in transient expression as- says. One of these fusions, DER, has been examined in detail to determine its mechanism of action. Results from immunoprecipitation experiments with extracts from DER and Fos transfected cells demonstrate that Fos and DER readily form heterodimer complexes. Sur- prisingly, the formation of Fos:DER heterodimers, and possibly DER homodimers, is estrogen-independent. However, gel shift assays clearly demonstrate that DNA binding to API sites by Fos:DER heterodimers or DER homodimers is estrogen-dependent. Moreover, in the ab- sence of estrogen, the DER protein is an effective inhib- itor of Fos-mediated transactivation, and this effect is reversed by the presence of estrogen. Our results indi- cate that the DER protein is a direct, hormone-revers- ible inhibitor of Fos and that estrogen controls the con- ditional positive or dominant negative activities of DER at the level of DNA binding to API sites. Accordingly, clonally derived fibroblast cell lines that stably express the DER protein exhibit reduced entry into the S phase of the cell eyele when quiescent cells are serum stimu- lated in the absence of estrogen. This is in contrast to the estrogen-treated controls. These results support the hypothesis that Al'1 is important for cell cycle progres- sion and provide a unique approach for examining the role of APJ in this process.
Members of the Jun and Fos families of oncoproteins are the essential components of the dimeric transcription factor acti- vator protein-1 (AP1).' The three members of the jun gene
* This work was supported by Public Health Service Grants CA- 52752 and CA-06927-31 from the National Cancer Institute, Grant 3805 from the Council for Tobacco Research, and a grant from Bristol- Myers Oncology Division (to D. S.). The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges. This article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.S.C. Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
1 Fellow of the National Institutes of Health and recipient of Grant F32CA-09219.
Â§ Fellow of the American Cancer Society.
1 To whom correspondence should be addressed Tel .: 215-728-2889, Fax: 215-728-3616.
1 The abbreviations used are: API, activator protein-1; GR, glucocor- ticoid receptor; KR, estrogen receptor; WI, wild type; ICH, polymerase chain reaction; CAT, chloramphenicol acetyl transferase; DMEM, Dul-
family, c.jun, junB, and junD), all undergo similar, but not identical, regulation and encode proteins that share a high degree of amino acid sequence identity (1). They are also sim- ilar in their interaction with c-Fos and Fos-related proteins (2). Jun:Jun or Jun:Fos dimer complexes bind to DNA at API sites and regulate the expression of target genes. Since jun and fos family members are rapidly induced in response to extracellu- lar growth signals, they are classified as immediate early re- sponse genes. Expression of these two gene families is an integral part of a well-orchestrated cascade of events leading to cellular proliferation (1 and 3,and references therein). Since Jun proteins are important participants in the cellular growth response, further studies analyzing the direct effects of these proteins on gene expression and cell growth would be greatly facilitated by a well characterized inducible expression system.
One approach for creating an inducible system focuses on placing the activity of a protein under the control of the ligand- binding domain of a steroid hormone receptor such as the glucocorticoid receptor (GR) or the estrogen receptor (ER). Ste- roid receptor fusion proteins have been created with proteins such as EIA (4), c-Myc (5), the CCAAT/enhancer-binding pro- tein (6), Myol) (7), p53 (8), and e-Fos (9, 10). In each of these cases, the fusion protein appeared to be devoid of biological activity when expressed in cells in the absence of hormone, whereas its appropriate wild type (WI') function was restored in the presence of hormone.
We explored the possibility that the activities of WT and mutated Jun proteins could be regulated post-translationally by fusion with the KR. A JunD) chimeric molecule was created by appending a truncated human ER sequence to its 3' end resulting in the JunD-ER (DER) fusion. Analysis of the DER fusion protein shows that it is estrogen dependent for the activation of transcription from API reporter constructs. In addition, a detailed analysis of the mechanism by which estro- gen regulates the DER protein was performed. The chimera forms heterodimers with WT Fos proteins but does not readily form heterodimers with WI Jun proteins. However, neither the weak interactions between DEK and WT Jun nor the strong interactions between DER and Fos are regulated by estrogen.
In contrast, DNA binding by DER homodimers or DER:Fos heterodimers is completely estrogen-dependent. Because of this novel mechanism of action, the DER fusion protein is an effective dominant negative protein that complexes with Fos and reversibly inhibits its DNA binding activity. In addition, cell clones that stably express the DER protein exhibit a re- duced capacity to enter S phase from a growth arrested state in the absence of estrogen, a result that is consistent with the hypothesis that API is important for normal cell cycle progression.
While a number of recombinant chimeras between steroid
becco's modified Eagle's medium; FHS, fetal bovine serum; TR, thyroid hormone receptor, RAK, retinoic acid receptor.

Analysis of the Hormone-dependent Regulation of a JunD-Estrogen
Receptor Chimera*
(Received for publication, November 14, 1994, and in revised form, February 1, 1995)
Mary Kay Francist, Donald G. Phinneys, and Kevin Rydert
From the Fox Chase Cancer Center, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19111
The modular ligand-binding domains of steroid recep-
tors have been widely used to generate protein chimeras
that are ligand dependent for activity. In a similar man-
ner, we generated a series of conditionally active JunD)
and c-Fos proteins by fusing their carboxyl (COOH)-
terminal ends with a COOH-terminal fragment of the
human estrogen receptor (KR) that contains the ligand-
binding domain. JunD-ER (DER) and Fos-ER (FER) chi-
meras with an intact leucine zipper and basic region
exhibit hormone-dependent activation of activator pro-
tein-1-directed transcription in transient expression as-
says. One of these fusions, DER, has been examined in
detail to determine its mechanism of action. Results
from immunoprecipitation experiments with extracts
from DER and Fos transfected cells demonstrate that
Fos and DER readily form heterodimer complexes. Sur-
prisingly, the formation of Fos:DER heterodimers, and
possibly DER homodimers, is estrogen-independent.
However, gel shift assays clearly demonstrate that DNA
binding to API sites by Fos:DER heterodimers or DER
homodimers is estrogen-dependent. Moreover, in the ab-
sence of estrogen, the DER protein is an effective inhib-
itor of Fos-mediated transactivation, and this effect is
reversed by the presence of estrogen. Our results indi-
cate that the DER protein is a direct, hormone-revers-
ible inhibitor of Fos and that estrogen controls the con-
ditional positive or dominant negative activities of DER
at the level of DNA binding to API sites. Accordingly,
clonally derived fibroblast cell lines that stably express
the DER protein exhibit reduced entry into the S phase
of the cell eyele when quiescent cells are serum stimu-
lated in the absence of estrogen. This is in contrast to
the estrogen-treated controls. These results support the
hypothesis that Al'1 is important for cell cycle progres-
sion and provide a unique approach for examining the
role of APJ in this process.

essential components of the dimeric transcription factor acti-
vator protein-1 (AP1).' The three members of the jun gene

family, c.jun, junB, and junD), all undergo similar, but not
identical, regulation and encode proteins that share a high
degree of amino acid sequence identity (1). They are also sim-
ilar in their interaction with c-Fos and Fos-related proteins (2).
Jun:Jun or Jun:Fos dimer complexes bind to DNA at API sites
and regulate the expression of target genes. Since jun and fos
family members are rapidly induced in response to extracellu-
lar growth signals, they are classified as immediate early re-
sponse genes. Expression of these two gene families is an
integral part of a well-orchestrated cascade of events leading to
cellular proliferation (1 and 3,and references therein). Since
Jun proteins are important participants in the cellular growth
response, further studies analyzing the direct effects of these
proteins on gene expression and cell growth would be greatly
facilitated by a well characterized inducible expression system.

placing the activity of a protein under the control of the ligand-
binding domain of a steroid hormone receptor such as the
glucocorticoid receptor (GR) or the estrogen receptor (ER). Ste-

such as EIA (4), c-Myc (5), the CCAAT/enhancer-binding pro-
tein (6), Myol) (7), p53 (8), and e-Fos (9, 10). In each of these
cases, the fusion protein appeared to be devoid of biological
activity when expressed in cells in the absence of hormone,
whereas its appropriate wild type (WI') function was restored
in the presence of hormone.
We explored the possibility that the activities of WT and
mutated Jun proteins could be regulated post-translationally
by fusion with the KR. A JunD) chimeric molecule was created
by appending a truncated human ER sequence to its 3' end
resulting in the JunD-ER (DER) fusion. Analysis of the DER
fusion protein shows that it is estrogen dependent for the

gen regulates the DER protein was performed. The chimera

heterodimers is completely estrogen-dependent. Because of

effective dominant negative protein that complexes with Fos
and reversibly inhibits its DNA binding activity. In addition,

duced capacity to enter S phase from a growth arrested state
in the absence of estrogen, a result that is consistent with
the hypothesis that API is important for normal cell cycle
progression.

Analysis of the Hormone-dependent Regulation of a JunD-Estrogen Receptor Chimera*
(Received for publication, November 14, 1994, and in revised form, February 1, 1995)
Mary Kay Francist, Donald G. Phinneys, and Kevin Rydert
From the Fox Chase Cancer Center, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19111

The modular ligand-binding domains of steroid recep- tors have been widely used to generate protein chimeras that are ligand dependent for activity. In a similar man- ner, we generated a series of conditionally active JunD) and c-Fos proteins by fusing their carboxyl (COOH)- terminal ends with a COOH-terminal fragment of the human estrogen receptor (KR) that contains the ligand- binding domain. JunD-ER (DER) and Fos-ER (FER) chi- meras with an intact leucine zipper and basic region exhibit hormone-dependent activation of activator pro- tein-1-directed transcription in transient expression as- says. family, c.jun, junB, and junD), all undergo similar, but not identical, regulation and encode proteins that share a high degree of amino acid sequence identity (1). They are also sim- ilar in their interaction with c-Fos and Fos-related proteins (2). Jun:Jun or Jun:Fos dimer complexes bind to DNA at API sites and regulate the expression of target genes. Since jun and fos family members are rapidly induced in response to extracellu- lar growth signals, they are classified as immediate early re- sponse genes. Expression of these two gene families is an integral part of a well-orchestrated cascade of events leading to cellular proliferation (1 and 3,and references therein). Because of this novel mechanism of action, the DER fusion protein is an effective dominant negative protein that complexes with Fos and reversibly inhibits its DNA binding activity. In addition, cell clones that stably express the DER protein exhibit a re- duced capacity to enter S phase from a growth arrested state in the absence of estrogen, a result that is consistent with the hypothesis that API is important for normal cell cycle progression.
